z.h: According to wikipedia, this moth, native to south Florida and the American tropics, doesn't survive our winters but migrates north each year. It feeds on flower nectar.
z.id: ID confirmed by bugguide ("There's really no other species in the USA that looks anything like this.").

z.h: Caterpillars feed on oak leaves (apparently any species of oak will do).
From bugguide: "larvae feed on alfalfa, clover, grasses, and Great Ragweed (Ambrosia trifida)".

From bugguide: "larvae are generalist feeders on more than 40 species of plants, including alfalfa, aster, blueberry, chickweed, clover, corn, dock, flax, goldenrod, garden vegetables, grasses, mullein, oats, plantain, raspberry, rye, tobacco, wheat."
z.id: This one is well worn, but note the white (shiny) vein that branches at the left side of the large spot - see the links for much better pictures and more info on id. ID confirmed by bugguide.
From bugguide: "186 species are found in America north of Mexico ... a difficult group with genitalia study often needed [for species identification]." ID confirmed by bugguide.

z.h: From bugguide: "Introduced from Europe to Nova Scotia in 1979, this species has since spread north to the Arctic Ocean, west to the Pacific, and south to the Gulf of Mexico."
z.id: I would say the "yellow underwing" of the common name is actually more often orange - see the links for images (the underwing isn't visible in these images).

z.h: Caterpillars feed on wood sorrel (Oxalis) species; apparently the only known moth or butterfly species to do so (at least as of 30 years ago - see the bugguide link for more information).
z.id: This is a male; the females are much darker.

z.h: From bugguide: "Larvae feed on a variety of plants (herbs), including soybeans, goldenrod, lettuce, sweet potato, and peanut. Other hosts include cotton, tomato, brassicas (cabbage, kale, broccoli), pea, tobacco, and cocklebur."
z.id: I couldn't decide between C. includens and Autographa precationis ( http://bugguide.net/node/view/7237 ), in spite of the guidance provided on bugguide - bugguide says it's C. includens. Autographa preactionis : http://bugguide.net/node/view/7238

z.h: Caterpillars feed on grape and Virginia creeper; adults fly during the day.
z.id: (The moth in the second picture was clearly injured; that's not a typical wing position.)

z.h: Common, often in "weedy" areas. From bugguide: "larvae feed on celery, grasses, Lucerne or Alfalfa (Medicago sativa), smartweed (Polygonum spp.), sweet clover (Melilotus spp.) and various other low herbaceous plants".
Most active dusk to dawn, but may also fly during the day, feeding on flower nectar.
z.id: See the links for some great pictures of this moth in full flight.

z.h: Though a bumble bee mimic in coloration, this moth is more likely to be mistaken for a hummingbird in behavior as it flits around the prairie and hovers at flowers to drink nectar.

z.id: The "T" airplane shape of these moths at rest is typical of plume moths in general (family Pterophoridae). My guess is this is Hellinsia kellicottii - Goldenrod Borer Plume Moth: http://bugguide.net/node/view/302202 http://mothphotographersgroup.msstate.edu/species.php?hodges=6212

z.h: See the following link for a list of some of the caterpillar hosts of this species, including pasqueflower and chokecherry: http://globalspecies.org/ntaxa/1547111
From bugguide: "larvae feed on bittersweet, bedstraw, corn, goldenrod, chestnut, oak, willow, and other plants."
The larval host of this species is sumac.
z.id: The long bristles on the legs can actually be found on a number of different kinds of moths. IDed (from genus to species) by bugguide.

I don't know what species this is, and identification might not be possible since it looks like most of the scales have been rubbed off the wings, but I'm keeping it here because of the antennae, the shape of which is typical of many male moths. The males use their feathery antennae to detect the presence of pheromones released by female moths and to home in on their location, in some cases from miles away! For more information, see, for example, this link: http://www.asknature.org/wedbg.php/strategy/b25d523b27046c43a503564f8aa1a4c6#changeTab

z.h: According to http://www.nhm.ac.uk/research-curation/research/projects/hostplants/search/index.dsml this species' host is staghorn sumac (Rhus hirta), meaning the caterpillars of this moth feed on the leaves of staghorn sumac.
